entity.name: Asutosh Rath
entity.description: I'm a recent graduate from NITK Surathkal, currently working as an Integrity Engineer at ExxonMobil in Bengaluru. During the severe Delhi air quality crisis, I found myself questioning a fundamental gap in how we measure air pollution: government AQI readings come from sparse monitoring stations, often kilometers away from where people actually live and breathe. A mother in Koramangala checking the AQI on her phone sees a reading from BTM Layout — but that's not the air her child is breathing at the neighborhood park. This realization sparked Project Vaayu: an open-source, affordable, accurate air quality monitor that anyone can use to know what they're actually breathing, right here, right now. I bring hands-on experience with Arduino, Raspberry Pi, and electronics prototyping, combined with access to 3D printing for enclosure development.

projects.name: Project Vaayu
projects.description:
Project Vaayu (Sanskrit for 'wind/air') is an open-source hardware initiative to create an affordable (₹5,000 / ~$60 USD) air quality monitoring device that enables hyperlocal AQI measurement anywhere in India.

**The Problem:**
Government CPCB stations are sparse — a city like Bangalore has only a handful of monitors for 13 million people. When you check AQI on your phone, you see the reading from a station that might be 5-10km away. But air quality varies dramatically block-by-block: near a construction site vs. a park, a busy intersection vs. a residential lane. People make health decisions (morning walks, children's outdoor play, opening windows) based on data that doesn't represent their actual air.

**The Solution:**
Vaayu is a portable, USB-C powered device that displays real-time PM2.5 AQI readings. Key features:
• ±10% accuracy target through environmental correction (humidity/temperature) and auto-calibration against CPCB API
• No app required — just a clear OLED display showing AQI number and category (Good/Moderate/Unhealthy/etc.)
• One-time WiFi setup for auto-calibration, then works completely offline
• Weather-resistant enclosure for outdoor use
• Fully open-source: hardware designs, firmware, enclosure STL files, and documentation

**Why Open Source Matters:**
Air pollution is India's largest environmental health threat, reducing life expectancy by 5+ years on average. Making accurate monitoring accessible isn't just a product opportunity — it's a public health imperative. Open-sourcing Vaayu enables community replication, localized improvements, and eventually a crowdsourced hyperlocal air quality network across Indian cities.

**Technical Approach:**
• Plantower PMS5003 laser particle sensor for PM2.5/PM10 measurement
• BME280 for temperature/humidity (enables correction algorithms)
• ESP32-C3 microcontroller with native USB-C and WiFi
• 0.96" OLED display for instant AQI readout
• India-specific correction factors tuned against CPCB reference data
• Auto-calibration via CPCB public API — no user travel to reference stations required

plans.name: Complete Development to Open-Source Release
plans.description:
Funding to take Project Vaayu from concept to fully documented open-source release.

**Milestone 1 (Month 1-2): Breadboard Prototype — ₹25,000**
• Procure components (PMS5003, ESP32-C3, BME280, OLED display)
• Assemble breadboard prototype
• Basic firmware: sensor reading + display
• Initial accuracy testing against nearest CPCB station
• Deliverable: Working prototype, initial accuracy report

**Milestone 2 (Month 2-3): Correction Algorithms — ₹20,000**
• Implement humidity correction formula (peer-reviewed research-based)
• Implement temperature correction
• Validate accuracy improvement against CPCB readings
• Deliverable: Correction algorithm code, accuracy comparison data

**Milestone 3 (Month 3-4): Auto-Calibration System — ₹30,000**
• WiFi provisioning (captive portal setup)
• CPCB API integration for real-time reference data
• Calibration factor calculation and storage
• Edge case handling (no WiFi, API errors, sensor warm-up)
• Deliverable: Complete calibration system, user flow documentation

**Milestone 4 (Month 4-5): Enclosure & Integration — ₹35,000**
• Design weather-resistant enclosure with proper airflow
• 3D print iterations (3-5 revisions expected)
• Thermal management validation
• Full integration testing
• Real-world testing: hot afternoon, monsoon humidity, dusty conditions
• Deliverable: Final enclosure STL files, integration test report

**Milestone 5 (Month 5-6): Documentation & Release — ₹20,000**
• Complete bill of materials with India sourcing links
• Step-by-step assembly guide with photos
• Firmware documentation and code cleanup
• Calibration user guide
• Blog post / forum announcement
• Deliverable: GitHub release with all artifacts, documentation site

**Budget Breakdown:**
• Components (5 prototype units): ₹20,000
• PCB fabrication: ₹8,000
• 3D printing filament + iterations: ₹7,000
• Reference device for validation: ₹15,000
• Testing across conditions (travel, time): ₹10,000
• Documentation hosting: ₹5,000
• Contingency: ₹15,000

**Community Engagement (per FOSS United requirements):**
• Quarterly updates on FOSS United forum
• Talk submission to IndiaFOSS / relevant meetups
• Open to mentoring through FOSS in Education programs
